title: The Diagnosis Is Celiac Disease: Now What?

content: So you’ve just gotten a diagnosis of celiac disease for yourself or someone in your family. And you’re realizing you need to find alternatives to staple foods like bread and pasta and figure out a new way of grocery shopping, label reading, and ordering in restaurants. Your head may be spinning.
“Starting out with a gluten-free lifestyle can be overwhelming,” says Jodi Danen, a registered dietitian who runs the online gluten-free community called “Create Kids Club.”
So I asked Danen, plus some other folks in my life who are living gluten-free, for their best post-diagnosis tips. Here’s their advice:

Make a list. Write down all the naturally gluten-free foods you already love instead of focusing on what you need to avoid. A lot of foods are naturally gluten-free, like fruits and vegetables, beans, eggs, meat, yogurt, and oatmeal. Seeing that list can help put you at ease and shift your perspective.

Get a buddy. Find a friend — or friend of a friend — who is already gluten-free and can guide you, give you tried-and-true recommendations for gluten-free products, and be a sounding board for asking questions (and maybe venting some occasional frustrations too!).

sections.heading: Have a good gluten-free flour.
content: Nobody wants to give up homemade baked goods like cookies and muffins. Making those will be a lot easier with a great gluten-free swap for all-purpose flour (the friend who gave this advice raves about King Arthur Gluten-Free Flour).
Pack safe foods. When traveling, options are unpredictable. So pack some safe gluten-free foods in your bag or car so you’re never caught off guard.

Know the code words. When reading labels and ingredient lists, you’ll need to watch out for obvious words like “wheat,” “barley,” and “rye.” According to the Celiac Disease Foundation, less obvious ingredients that contain gluten include malt, malt flavor, malt extract, malt vinegar, and brewer’s yeast. And surprising foods that may contain gluten include potato chips, soups, salad dressings and sauces, and meat substitutes, so always read labels.

Alert your servers. When eating out, make sure your server knows that you have a medical reason to avoid gluten -- and that it’s not just a lifestyle choice -- and be sure they understand what that means. If possible, look at menus in advance to find gluten-free meals, and call the restaurant if you have questions.

sections.heading: Find a few staple recipes and restaurants.
content: You don’t have to have it all figured out at once. Danen suggests focusing on easy meals at first that are easily tweaked to be gluten-free, like tacos (using corn taco shells, corn tortillas, or tortillas labeled gluten-free) and pasta (using gluten-free noodles). Find at least one restaurant where it’s easy to eat gluten-free. Places like Chipotle, sushi restaurants (minus gluten-containing soy sauce), and Indian restaurants are all favorites of one gluten-free friend.

Know that you’ll find a new normal. Celiac disease can feel like a lot to process, but know that you will find plenty of things to eat, be able to order in a restaurant, and read labels like a pro. “Be patient and stay positive,” says Danen. “Adjusting takes time, but over time, gluten-free living will feel natural. And you and your family can still enjoy delicious food, fun celebrations, and happy, healthy lives.”
